awd_titl_txt: CAREER: From Fundamental Interactions to Emergent Phenomena: Geometrical Aspects of Nuclear Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The advent of experimental facilities with beams of radioactive, or unstable, atomic nuclei opens up new opportunities for the low-energy nuclear physics community to study the properties of rare nuclear isotopes, improve the understanding of fundamental interactions, and develop applications with direct societal impact, including in medicine, homeland security, and industry. Experimental information on exotic nuclear systems plays a key role for understanding the elemental composition of the universe and for predicting the evolution of stars and galaxies. In this context, nuclear theory is called upon to provide missing information about exotic nuclei that are not accessible experimentally. To this effort, this project will contribute an implementation of novel ideas on nuclear dynamics. The theory will be benchmarked against state-of-the-art experimental data. In addition to training graduate students by engaging them in this research, the project includes outreach and education activities, such as art-science exhibitions and graduate courses, aimed at attracting young talents to the field of nuclear physics. 

This project addresses fundamental theoretical questions about the microscopic mechanisms responsible for the binding of loosely-bound nuclei, their shapes and decay properties, and for spectra of their excitations. The project emphasizes the geometrical aspects of nuclear dynamics: intrinsic deformations, coupling to the continuum, and shapes and spatial density distributions associated with nuclear superfluidity. The approach developed here will account for emergent collective phenomena in medium-mass and heavy nuclei with higher accuracy and predictive power that are crucial for astrophysical applications. Comparison to results of recent and future experiments at major nuclear physics facilities, such as NSCL/FRIB and RIKEN, will constrain both the underlying nuclear forces and the many-body coupling mechanisms included in the theory.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

 The project made significant progress in various areas of nuclear theory, including nuclear response dynamics, complex quasiparticle-phonon interactions, and modeling deformed nuclear systems. These advancements have implications for astrophysics, quantum computing, and fundamentals of in-medium fermionic interactions.

  1. The core of the project was advancing the Relativistic Nuclear Field Theory (RNFT), a theoretical framework designed to bridge fundamental interactions and nuclear low-energy phenomenology. By deriving emergent collectivity through a general class of correlation functions, RNFT addressed several major long-standing problems in nuclear physics, including weak processes and the nuclear equation of state. The central conceptual advancement was formulating the strongly coupled many-body theory with the bare interaction between nucleons as the only input and deriving a class of controlled approximations adequately capturing collective degrees of freedom from the exact equations of motion.
  2. The numerical implementations of RNFT for the response of medium-heavy nuclei to external probes were advanced to the solutions with higher complexity of quantum states than was previously possible. The hierarchy of solutions of growing complexity organized according to an order parameter associated with emergent collectivity was shown to be reasonably converging, and thus, configuration complexity can be used as a reliable criterion of uncertainty for a many-body approach. The new computational solutions demonstrated improved accuracy and predictive power over a wide range of nuclear spectral properties.
  3. As the nuclear many-body problem can not be solved exactly, finding increasingly accurate solutions constitutes the path to nuclear spectroscopy, whose experimental techniques have progressed to resolve fine details of excited states. Our calculations showed that both gross and fine spectral features in wide energy intervals, including giant resonances and soft modes, can be approached now closer than ever by a self-consistent theory.                
  4. Accurate and predictive nuclear structure theory is critical for astrophysical applications, precision studies of fundamental symmetries, and new physics searches. The beta decay sector of RNFT, involved in the astrophysical modeling of neutron star mergers and core-collapse supernovae, was advanced to comprise first-forbidden transitions and complex ground state correlations, which capture essential contributions to the beta decay rates beyond the standardly included ones. Furthermore, the theory with the particle-phonon couping in the leading approximation was formulated and implemented for finite-temperature calculations, enabling a significant step forward in providing reliable input for stellar simulations.  
  5. Geometrical aspects of nuclear structure were accessed through spatial density distributions in static and dynamic regimes. Static deformations were integrated into the beyond-mean-field and generalized response theories based on the bare Hamiltonian by formulating it in the most model-independent form, allowing for dynamical superfluidity. The implementations with the quasiparticle-phonon couping in the leading approximation were performed on an axially-deformed basis and validated in structure calculations for axially-deformed nuclei. Dynamical shapes were generated and visualized via transition densities between complex states. This facet of the project enables “nuclear tomography”, i.e., graphic visualizations of the nuclear matter distribution in various processes based on the correspondence between quantum correlations and spatial arrangement of strongly coupled nucleons.  
  6. A quantum algorithm for the computation of the many-body fermionic response was developed and tested on an exactly solvable model across the coupling regimes. These studies reveal a substantial quantum benefit in the efficient generation of complex configurations by the quantum equation of motion method. The algorithm can be useful for precision calculations of other strongly interacting systems, where the direct generation of complex configurations can be extremely costly. 

The Broader Impact of this project includes (i) significance for nuclear physics, many-body theory, astrophysics, and quantum computation, (ii) training the next generation of scientists, (iii) raising the profile of underrepresented minorities, and (iv) integrating the forefront research into the university’s curriculum. 

The project made broader impacts ranging from on-campus to international. Its research activities addressed several key issues of the Nuclear Science Advisory Committee's long-range plan, particularly the emergence of collective effects in heavy nuclei from the underlying strong forces and tackling the nuclear many-body problem with quantum algorithms. The developed theory provided support for several experiments at major nuclear physics facilities. The designed methods are applicable beyond nuclear structure, extending to a broad class of condensed matter systems, cold atoms, electronic systems, and high-temperature superconductors. The astrophysical implications of the advanced nuclear response theory include refined modeling of the star evolution. The devised hybrid quantum-classical algorithms enhanced quantum computing initiatives in the US and worldwide. The project gave the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers a unique opportunity to advance forefront knowledge, establish their independent research lines, and create the potential to become future leaders in nuclear theory and related areas. Thereby, the project has contributed significantly to an internationally competitive workforce in nuclear theory and quantum computing.
